{{about|the original version|the high-definition version|Final Fantasy Type-0 HD}} {{featured article}}
{{Infobox video game | title = Final Fantasy Type-0 | image = FF Type-0 cover.jpg | developer = [[Square Enix#Development organization|Square Enix 1st Production Department]]<ref name="4gamer1st" /> | publisher = [[Square Enix]] | director = [[Hajime Tabata]]<ref name="SilCrew"/> | producer = [[Yoshinori Kitase]]<ref name="SilCrew"/> | artist = {{Plainlist| * [[Yusuke Naora]]<ref name="AndriaStaff"/> * Yusaku Nakaaki<ref name="AndriaStaff"/> * [[Tetsuya Nomura]]<ref name="AndriaType0story"/> }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * Hiroki Chiba<ref name="Type0writer"/> * Sarah Okabe<ref name="Type0writer2"/> * Hajime Tabata<ref name="T0update"/> }} | composer = [[Takeharu Ishimoto]]<ref name="Type0music"/> | series = {{Plainlist| * ''[[Fabula Nova Crystallis Final Fantasy|Fabula Nova Crystallis]]'' * ''[[Final Fantasy]]'' }} | platforms = [[PlayStation Portable]] | released = {{Video game release|JP|October 27, 2011<ref name="T0delay"/>}} | genre = [[Action role-playing game|Action role-playing]]<ref name="1up_type0"/> | modes = {{Plainlist| *[[Single-player video game|Single-player]] *[[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} }} {{Nihongo foot|'''''Final Fantasy Type-0'''''|ファイナルファンタジー零式|Fainaru Fantajī Reishiki|lead=yes|group=Jp.}} is an [[action role-playing game]] developed and published by [[Square Enix]] for the [[PlayStation Portable]] (PSP). Released in Japan on October 27, 2011, ''Type-0'' is part of the ''[[Fabula Nova Crystallis Final Fantasy|Fabula Nova Crystallis]]'' subseries, a set of games sharing a common mythos which includes ''[[Final Fantasy XIII]]'' and ''[[Final Fantasy XV]]''. The gameplay, similar to ''[[Crisis Core: Final Fantasy VII]]'', has the player taking control of characters in real-time combat during missions across Orience. The player also engages in large-scale strategy-based battles on the world map, and has access to a multiplayer option during story missions and side quests.
The story focuses on Class Zero, a group of fourteen students from the Vermillion Peristylium, a magical academy in the Dominion of Rubrum. When the Militesi Empire launches an assault on the other Crystal States of Orience, seeking to control their respective crystals, Class Zero is mobilized for the defense of Rubrum. Eventually, the group becomes entangled in the secrets behind both the war and the reason for their existence. The setting and presentation were inspired by historical documentaries, and the story itself was written to be darker than other ''Final Fantasy'' titles.
The game was originally announced as a title for mobile phones and the PSP called {{Nihongo foot|''Final Fantasy Agito XIII''.|ファイナルファンタジーアギトXIII|Fainaru Fantajī Agito Sātīn|group=Jp.}} It was directed by [[Hajime Tabata]], who took up the project after completing ''[[Before Crisis: Final Fantasy VII]]''. Initially designed to provide players with easy access to the ''Fabula Nova Crystallis'' universe, the mobile version was eventually cancelled and the game's title was changed to distance it from the subseries' flagship title ''Final Fantasy XIII''. Releasing to strong sales, it received praise for its story and gameplay, but was criticized for its camera control and [[Artificial intelligence (video games)|artificial intelligence]]. Further games related to ''Type-0'' have also been developed, including a [[Final Fantasy Type-0 HD|high definition remaster]] that released internationally in March 2015. {{TOC limit|3}}
==Gameplay== ''Final Fantasy Type-0'' is an [[action role-playing video game]] in which the player controls the 14 members of Class Zero, who are sent on missions across Orience. Outside environments such as the Vermillion Peristylium (Class Zero's home base) and dedicated missions, the game world of Orience is navigated via a scaled-down [[overworld|world map]]. Class Zero are sent on missions across Orience during the course of the game. The player initially travels to preset destinations in the world on an airship supplied by the Peristylium, but gains their own airship to freely navigate the world map with after defeating a powerful enemy guarding it.<ref name="AndraiType02"/><ref name="RPGreview"/> The main gameplay is presented in a mission-based structure.<ref name="1up_type0"/> The two types of missions encountered are story-based missions, and "Practice" missions, which act as side-quests.<ref name="AndriaSummons"/> During missions, optional orders are issued which can be obeyed or ignored as the player chooses. Should they be accepted, the characters receive a temporary power boost, and completing the objectives yields rewards.<ref name="1up_type0"/><ref name="AndriaSummons"/> Players can also engage in real-time strategy battles on the world map, with the player taking control of allied military divisions. Missions involve liberating cities and towns from enemy forces.<ref name="IGN1"/> Timed aerial missions are also available where the characters shoot down attacking dragons using their airship's weapons.<ref name="SilSleep"/>
While outside combat, players can breed [[chocobo]]s, recurring [[galliform]] birds in the ''Final Fantasy'' series. Players must capture two chocobos on the world map and take them to a special ranch within the Peristylium: by pairing certain chocobos and adding specific items, a special chocobo can be bred for use. Players can visit the Peristylium Crystarium to review defeated enemies, character information, in-game lore and special video clips.<ref name="AndraiType02"/> [[Character design of Final Fantasy#Moogle|Moogles]], another recurring creature in the series, hand out missions to the player: the objectives of missions can change during gameplay. Items and new equipment can be bought from shops managed by [[non-player character]]s (NPCs) both within the Peristylium and across Orience. Towns liberated during missions give access to a wider range of shops.<ref name="IGN1"/> After completing the game once, players unlock a "[[New Game+]]" option: in this mode, players keep their stats and weapons from the previous playthrough, while also unlocking story scenes and character-specific missions.<ref name="AndriaType0story"/> ''Type-0'' features three difficulty levels; "normal", "hard", and "impossible".<ref name="SilDifficulty"/>
===Battle system=== [[File:FF Type-0 PSP gameplay.jpg|left|thumb|Screenshot of combat in ''Final Fantasy Type-0'', showing characters Ace, Machina and Rem in combat with one of the game's common enemies.]] ''Type-0'' uses a [[Real-time game|real-time]], [[Action role-playing game|action-based]] battle system similar to the system used in ''[[Crisis Core: Final Fantasy VII]]''. The player is allowed access to three characters, which they can swap between at any time. The two not being controlled are managed by the game's [[Artificial intelligence (video games)|artificial intelligence]].<ref name="1up_type0"/> Each character has a specific weapon, and special attacks unique to a character are unlocked as they gain [[experience level]]s.<ref name="SilSleep"/> During combat, characters lock onto targets while attacking and can switch targets.<ref name="1up_type0"/> Characters are able to perform precisely timed attacks during the period when an enemy unit is attacking: the "Break Sight", which deals high damage, and the "Kill Sight", which kills a standard enemy with a single hit.<ref name="IGN2"/> Three characters can also be commanded to use a {{Nihongo foot|Triad Maneuver,|三位一体|Sanmi Ittai|"Trinity Attack"|group=Jp.}} combining their attacks to deal higher damage to a target.<ref name="Type0trinity"/> Aside from human enemies, the game features multiple recurring ''Final Fantasy'' monsters.<ref name="AndraiType02"/> In addition to enemies encountered in missions, there are special enemies that can be encountered while exploring the world map.<ref name="AndriaSummons"/>
Defeated enemy units drop a substance called Phantoma. The color of Phantoma indicates what aspect of the character it will replenish, though in general they automatically replenish a set amount of [[Magic (gaming)|magic points]]. Phantoma are used in the game's leveling system, the Altocrystarium, to strengthen a character's magic skills.<ref name="AndriaGameplay"/> The game's magic skills are divided into five basic groups named after types of guns: for example, "Rifle" fires the spell in a straight line, while "Missile" homes in on and chases targeted enemies.<ref name="AndriaSummons"/><ref name="Type0guns"/> Holding down the assigned action button increases the power of the attack.<ref name="Type0summontypes"/> Many combat situations involve timed challenges. Success rewards the character, while failure drains their health. If a character is defeated in battle, the player can instantly select another to replace it, and the defeated character must be revived outside the mission.<ref name="IGN2"/> The game features an arena where practice fights take place. While these fights are not against real foes, the characters continue to [[experience point|level up]] and gain Phantoma after the battle, and twenty battles can be arranged at any one time.<ref name="SilSleep"/> Each character has access to [[Gameplay of Final Fantasy#Magic|summoned monsters]] called {{Nihongo foot|Eidolons,|軍神|Gunshin|"War Gods"|group=Jp.}} which act as temporary playable characters and have their own set of skills. Summoning them empties the selected character's health gauge, removing them from battle until they are revived. Summons are also affected by the current environment: as an example, Shiva's powers are stronger in snowy weather. After a limited time in battle, the Eidolons are dismissed. Those available to players are series staples Shiva, Ifrit, Golem, Odin, Diablos and Bahamut.<ref name="AndriaSummons"/><ref name="IGN2"/><ref name="SilDiablos"/><ref name="AndriaMultiplayer"/> Each Eidolon has variants of its original form, many of which are unlocked as the game progresses.<ref name="Type0summontypes"/>
Characters can continue to level up through activities within the Peristylium while the PSP is in sleep mode, the game's [[Universal Media Disc|UMD]] is running, and the PSP is charging. The multiplayer function, activated through the game's configuration screen, allows two other players to jump into another host player's game via an online connection. The allotted time for multiplayer is limited to a few minutes, with transitions between zones triggering the end of a multiplayer section. The time limit can be extended by players helping their current host. The first and last segments of the game are not open to multiplayer.<ref name="AndriaType0story"/><ref name="SilSleep"/><ref name="AndriaMultiplayer"/><ref name="AndraiType01"/> There is also a function called Magical Academy Assist, in which NPCs named after members of the game's production team are summoned into battle to assist the cadets.<ref name="Type0assist"/>
==Synopsis== ''Note: The plot of Type-0 is the same in its original version and the high-definition remaster [[Final Fantasy Type-0 HD]], so the terms and quotes used in the text are from the localization of the high-definition remaster rather than unofficial translations.''
===Setting=== ''Final Fantasy Type-0'' is set within Orience, a land divided between four nations or "Crystal States". Each nation has crystals of power based on the [[Four Symbols (China)|Four Symbols]], which are in turn their national emblems. The Dominion of Rubrum uses the [[Vermilion Bird|Vermillion Bird]] Crystal, which controls magic; the Milites Empire controls the [[White Tiger (China)|White Tiger]] Crystal, containing the power of science and weapons; the Kingdom of Concordia uses the [[Azure Dragon]] Crystal, containing the power of Dragons; and the Lorican Alliance is home to the [[Black Tortoise]] Crystal, containing the power of shielding. Each nation has an academy, or Peristylium, to research and protect the country's respective crystal.<ref name="OrienceDetails"/> The crystals have the ability to mark humans as their countries' servants. These servants, called l'Cie, are branded with a symbol and are given a "Focus", a task to complete. While blessed with long life and the ability to transform into crystal, l'Cie are cursed to lose their memories over time.<ref name="AndriaType02"/> The people of Orience also lose their memories of the dead so they will not be held back by any past regrets and continue strengthening their souls through conflict, a mechanism put in place by the crystals for the convenience of the deities who crafted them.<ref name="AndriaType0story"/><ref name="T0art"/> The main aim of many characters is to become Agito, a legendary figure who will appear and save the world from Tempus Finis, an apocalyptic event that will destroy Orience.<ref name="QUOTEagito"/>
===Characters=== {{Main article|Characters of the Final Fantasy Type-0 universe}} The main characters of ''Final Fantasy Type-0'' are Class Zero, an elite group of 14 students from the Vermillion Peristylium. The first 12 are card wielder [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Ace|Ace]], flute wielder [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Other Class Zero Members|Deuce]], the archer [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Other Class Zero Members|Trey]], magic-gun wielder [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Other Class Zero Members|Cater]], the mace-wielding [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Other Class Zero Members|Cinque]], scythe wielder [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Other Class Zero Members|Sice]], whip wielder [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Other Class Zero Members|Seven]], martial artist [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Other Class Zero Members|Eight]], spearman [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Other Class Zero Members|Nine]], katana wielding [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Other Class Zero Members|Jack]], swordswoman [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Other Class Zero Members|Queen]] and dual pistol wielding [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Other Class Zero Members|King]]. The last two, [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Machina Kunagiri|Machina Kunagiri]] and [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Rem Tokimiya|Rem Tokimiya]], double as narrators and the focus for the game's main subplot. Supporting Class Zero are their mentor [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Kurasame Susaya|Kurasame Susaya]], and [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Arecia Al-Rashia|Arecia Al-Rashia]], Class Zero's former mentor and the overseer for magical development at the Vermillion Peristylium. Other important characters from Rubrum are [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Dominion of Rubrum|Khalia Chival VI]], the current leader of Rubrum and headmaster of the Vermillion Peristyrium, and the l'Cie [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Dominion of Rubrum|Caetuna]]. Multiple Militesi figures, led by Marshal [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Cid Aulstyne|Cid Aulstyne]], act as the game's main antagonists. Other important characters include the Concordian queen [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Kingdom of Concordia|Andoria]], [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Gala|Gala]], leader of the Rursus Army and the instigator of Tempus Finis, and [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Joker|Joker]] and [[Characters of Final Fantasy Type-0 and Agito#Tiz|Tiz]], two mysterious figures who observe the events of the game.
===Plot=== Marshal Cid Aulstyne leads the army of Milites against the other nations of Orience, launching a devastating attack against the Vermillion Peristylium and neutralising the Vermillion Bird Crystal using a crystal jammer. Class Zero, immune to the effects of the jammer, repel the invasion.<ref name="QUOTErecapture"/> During the conflict Izana Kunagiri, Machina's older brother, is killed while on a mission for Class Zero. This event later creates a rift between Machina and Class Zero. Coordinated by Kurasame and Arecia Al-Rashia, Class Zero plays a key role in freeing Rubrum's territories and launching counterattacks in alliance with Concordia, while Lorica's capital is destroyed by a Militesi bomb. Andoria, Concordia's queen, then forces a ceasefire between the remaining nations.<ref name="QUOTEceasefire"/> During peace talks in the Militesi capital, Class Zero is framed for Andoria's murder, resulting in Concordia's puppet government and Milites launching a united assault on Rubrum.<ref name="QUOTEframed"/> During their flight, Machina storms off after clashing with Class Zero, and becomes a White Tiger l'Cie to protect Rem from his brother's fate before returning to them. The White Tiger Crystal's will eventually forces him to leave.<ref name="QUOTEmachinal'cie"/>
With help from its l'Cie soldiers and Class Zero, Rubrum destroys the forces of Concordia and Milites, uniting Orience under its flag.<ref name="QUOTEfronts"/><ref name="QUOTEsummon"/> This triggers the arrival of Tempus Finis, with the Rursus Army emerging from the magical fortress Pandaemonium to wipe out Orience's population.<ref name="QUOTEfinis"/> Cid and Class Zero each travel to Pandaemonium: Cid attempts to become Agito and is transformed into the Rursus Arbiter by Gala, while Class Zero resolve to halt Tempus Finis. As Class Zero face the trials of the Arbiter, the Vermillion Bird Crystal offers them the chance to become l'Cie. During the original playthrough, if Class Zero accepts the offer, they go into battle against the Rursus and die, dooming Orience to be destroyed in Tempus Finis and reborn in another spiral of history. <ref name="QUOTEspiral" />
Class Zero refuse the Crystal's offer and Rem is made a l'Cie in their place. Machina and Rem end up fighting each other in Pandaemonium: Rem is mortally wounded, and she and Machina turn to crystal. Severely weakened by the trials and demoralized at seeing Machina and Rem's condition, Class Zero are initially unable to defeat the Arbiter. Machina and Rem's spirits give them the strength they need to defeat the Arbiter and halt Tempus Finis. Fatally injured, Class Zero spend their final minutes imagining their possible post-war lives.<ref name="QUOTEend1"/> They are found by Machina and Rem, who have returned to human form and, along with the rest of Orience, are allowed to remember the dead. In a post-credits sequence, it is said that the Crystal States fall into turmoil as the Crystals lose their powers. Machina and Rem unite Orience and rebuild the world, and Machina records Class Zero's history before dying with Rem at his side.<ref name="T0art"/><ref name="QUOTEend2"/><ref name="FFType0_U"/>
A second playthrough reveals that Orience is trapped in a stable timeloop created by Arecia and Gala, the respective servants of the deities [[Fabula Nova Crystallis Final Fantasy#Common elements|Pulse and Lindzei]], as part of an experiment to find the gateway to the Unseen Realm.<ref name="FFType0_U"/> Competing with each other to open the gateway using a different method, both failed and reset the world for another attempt. By the events of ''Type-0'', the experiment had been performed over six hundred million times.<ref name="QUOTEmillion"/> Cid, aware of the cycle, wanted to free Orience from the Crystals' control, and killed himself in an unsuccessful attempt to prevent Gala from using him. In a sequence unlocked during the second playthrough, Joker and Tiz speak with Arecia after the Arbiter's defeat and show her the memories of Class Zero and the people of Orience to make her reconsider restarting the experiment.<ref name="QUOTEmemory1" /> After speaking with Machina and Rem, Arecia decides to abandon the experiment and returns the two to human form.<ref name="QUOTEmemory2" /> In an alternate ending, Arecia chooses to remove the crystals from Orience's history, creating a new timeline where the war never occurred and the world's population can live happily.<ref name="QUOTEspecial"/>
==Development== ''Final Fantasy Type-0'' was originally titled ''Final Fantasy Agito XIII'', envisioned as a game for mobile devices. It was conceived in 2005 as part of ''[[Fabula Nova Crystallis Final Fantasy]]'', a subseries of ''Final Fantasy'' games linked by a common mythos. ''Agito XIII'' was the final original ''Fabula Nova Crystallis'' game to be created. The decision to make it a mobile game was based on the popularity of ''[[Before Crisis: Final Fantasy VII]]''. [[Hajime Tabata]], who contributed to the ''Fabula Nova Crystallis'' mythos, was searching for a new project after finishing ''Before Crisis'' and became the game's director.<ref name="e32006"/><ref name="FNCinception"/> ''Before Crisis'' producer Kosei Ito acted as producer before his move to [[Capcom]] prior to 2009.<ref name="AgitoXIIIdetails"/><ref name="ItoCapcom"/> Beginning development in 2006, it was first announced at that year's [[Electronic Entertainment Expo]] (E3). It was said to offer on-the-go access to the ''Fabula Nova Crystallis'' universe, using gameplay functions exclusive to mobile phones of the time.<ref name="AgitoXIIIdetails"/><ref name="T0concept"/><ref name="FabulaUnveiled"/> The concept was to deliver a game for mobile platforms equivalent to a console game from the main ''Final Fantasy'' series, and to make it available in its entirety upon release rather than in episodic format.<ref name="fan"/>
Developers had been planning a release on the next generation of mobile phones, as those available at the time could not offer all the capabilities they would need.<ref name="fan"/> While it was originally claimed to be a mobile exclusive, versions for both mobiles and the [[PlayStation Portable]] were being developed, with the latter to be revealed when the former was sufficiently advanced.<ref name="AgitoXIIIpsp"/> The original staff members were Tabata, [[Yusuke Naora]] and [[Tetsuya Nomura]]. Nomura acted as a character designer and creative producer.<ref name="AndriaType0story"/> Between 2006 and 2008, development wavered between inactivity and sluggishness since most of the team was devoted to ''[[Crisis Core: Final Fantasy VII]]''. In 2008, it was said to be facing serious problems due to the scale of the project.<ref name="AndriaStaff"/><ref name="T0update"/> An issue developers had grappled with was whether or not to make the command buttons used in the game visible on the mobile screen.<ref name="Notes"/> ''Agito XIII'' was described as an online RPG using fully rendered 3D graphics similar to console games, as well as having gameplay elements from multiple genres such as [[Massively multiplayer online role-playing game|MMORPG]]s, smaller-scale multiplayer-focused games, and standard role-playing games.<ref name="T0update"/><ref name="fan"/><ref name="T0online"/><ref name="FamDevMobile"/> Other unfinished concepts being developed were a day-night cycle, a calendar system linked to real-world time and dates, and a story influenced by player votes.<ref name="T0art"/><ref name="HajimeSilInterview"/>
In 2008, it was decided to make ''Type-0'' a PSP exclusive, cancelling the mobile version of the game as the developers did not want to wait for mobile technology to reach a level which could handle their full vision for the game. Full development began that year by the same team who developed ''Crisis Core'', but was again slowed as most of them were completing work on ''[[The 3rd Birthday]]''.<ref name="AndriaType0story"/><ref name="Type-0Update"/><ref name="PSP"/><ref name="FamAgitoMobiles"/><ref name="Type0Wired"/> Because of these conflicting projects, ''Type-0'' came close to being cancelled outright.<ref name="Type0cancel"/> Between 2009 and 2011, the title was changed to distance it from ''Final Fantasy XIII'', since after the platform change the two games had little in common other than their shared mythos. One of the titles considered and rejected was ''Final Fantasy Live'', referring to the game's multiplayer element. The new title, ''Final Fantasy Type-0,'' was intended to indicate the game's separation from the main series. It was also the beginning of an alternative numbering system parallel to the main series.<ref name="FFType0_Uname"/><ref name="AgitoChange"/><ref name="Type0meaning"/> The game made its first official public appearance under the new title at the Square Enix 1st Production Department Premier in Tokyo, along with a new trailer that was released to the public on January 27, 2011.<ref name="JanAnnouncement"/>
===Scenario and design=== [[File:FF Type-0 key art.jpg|thumb|right|Artwork representing the themes and atmosphere of ''Type-0''. The artwork was created by the game's art director [[Yusuke Naora]], who drew on personal experience and the game's themes of war and death.<ref name="NaoraLecture"/>]] ''Type-0''{{'}}s scenario was conceived by Tabata and written by Hiroki Chiba and Sarah Okabe.<ref name="Type0writer"/><ref name="Type0writer2"/><ref name="T0update"/> While the game was still titled ''Agito XIII'', Tabata described it as "a major title [...] formed from a variety of concepts" which included the collision of four fantasies (the game's view of Orience), a battle between magic and weapons, and the two sides of reality.<ref name="T0themes"/> The early story concept drew heavily from popular [[manga]] and [[anime]], but little survived after the platform change. Tabata instead chose a new style similar to historical films and documentaries.<ref name="T0art"/> The new story's concept started with the idea of a war story told by young people caught up in the event, with its story themes revolving around death and its impact on others.<ref name="AndriaType0story"/> A major inspiration was the Japanese documentary series ''Centuries of Picture''. The final story was darker than many other ''Final Fantasy'' games.<ref name="T0art"/> Despite its title change, the game was kept within the ''Fabula Nova Crystallis'' mythos.<ref name="JanAnnouncement"/><ref name="dengeki"/> The approach taken with the mythos was to portray the roles of its deities from a historical standpoint, while telling a story focused on the human side of events.<ref name="AndriaType0story"/><ref name="Type-0Update"/><ref name="AndriaType0update"/> The cyclic nature of the game's universe was created to help incorporate aspects of the mythos.<ref name="Type0mythos"/> The roles and backgrounds for each character in the game were conceived and put into place after the setting and main story had been finalized.<ref name="SilNaora"/> After the game's release, Tabata commented that when he was writing the story he would have liked to have been more thorough, and to have made the story easier for players to understand.<ref name="GamespotTabata"/>
The game's logo artwork was drawn by regular series artist [[Yoshitaka Amano]].<ref name="Type0themesong"/> The kanji symbol used in the logo was drawn by Naora, who had designed the Shinra logo in ''[[Final Fantasy VII]]'' and its [[Compilation of Final Fantasy VII|companion media]]. Naora specifically requested that he draw the logo due to this previous experience.<ref name="AndriaType0update"/> To achieve the grittier atmosphere, Naora took a research trip to a Japanese military camp to learn what being a military cadet was like. The island of the Vermillion Perystilium was based on an offshore Japanese island he had visited prior to his involvement with the game, adding elements in-game such as an offshore ship wreck to symbolize his fear of the sea. He was also influenced by an incident where he saw a dead cat surrounded by other cats to portray the bond between members of Class Zero, and the game's themes, in promotional artwork.<ref name="NaoraLecture"/>
The gameplay was inspired by the multi-character system of ''Before Crisis'', while the naming of magic styles after weapons of war made reference to first-person shooters.<ref name="Type0guns"/> The combat was designed to be filled with tension and portray each playable character's personality on the battlefield.<ref name="GamespotTabata"/> The Eidolons were originally not controlled in realtime, but during the development of Ifrit, Tabata did some testing with real-time commands. The results impressed him enough that he decided to overcome the technical difficulties involved and make the Eidolons controllable.<ref name="T0JPinterview"/> Due to technical restrictions and the presence of the Academy Assist function, the game's [[Artificial intelligence (video games)|artificial intelligence]] for playable characters needed to be limited to healing, survival and other minor actions.<ref name="TabataReddit"/> The game's multiplayer was deliberately designed around restricted segments. Its development was still ongoing during the summer of 2011, with a [[2011 PlayStation Network outage|temporary stoppage]] of [[PlayStation Network]] that year negatively affecting its development.<ref name="AndriaMultiplayer"/> Because of the size of the project, debugging the game took far longer than anticipated. Between the release of the demo and the full game, adjustments were made to gameplay mechanics and the in-game camera.<ref name="AndriaType0story"/> In a post-release interview, Tabata commented that he would have liked to expand the multiplayer functions to include an ad-hoc function and expanded cooperative gameplay, and create a more forgiving learning curve for players.<ref name="GamespotTabata"/>
===Music=== {{Infobox album | italic_title = no | name = Final Fantasy Type-0 Original Soundtrack | type = Soundtrack | artist = [[Takeharu Ishimoto]] & [[Nobuo Uematsu]] | cover = | border = yes | alt = | released = October 26, 2011 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Video game music|Video game soundtrack]] | length = {{plainlist| *Disc 1: 56:54 *Disc 2: 1:04:21 *Disc 3: 1:07:34 *Total: 3:09:02 }} | label = [[Square Enix]] | producer = Takeharu Ishimoto | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} The music for ''Type-0'' was composed by [[Takeharu Ishimoto]]. He had previously composed the music for ''Before Crisis'', ''Crisis Core'' and ''[[The World Ends with You]]''. Ishimoto gave the music a dark and heavy feel, describing the themes as "war, life, and death". He used less [[Rock music|rock]] elements than in his previous games to promote a feeling of immersion. One of his primary instruments was the [[guitar]], which Ishimoto played himself during recording sessions.<ref name="Type0music"/><ref name="IshimotoInterview"/> Although the title was for the PSP, the team did not want to hold back despite hardware limitations, recording a quantity of tracks unusual for a spin-off ''Final Fantasy'' title. Wherever possible, the recording was done live.<ref name="IshimotoInterview"/> The orchestral and choral elements were performed by the [[Sydney Symphony Orchestra]] and the Cantillation chamber choir, and the recording and mixing of these tracks was done at the [[Sydney Opera House]]. Recording for other tracks was done at Ishimoto's studio in Japan.<ref name="IshimotoInterview"/><ref name="IshimotoT0HD"/><ref name="OSTliners"/> After recording, Ishimoto combined the orchestral and choral elements, and rearranged the main leitmotifs to create more variety in the score.<ref name="Type0music"/> Arrangements for the orchestral tunes were done by [[Kentaro Sato (composer)|Kentaro Sato]], while arrangements for other tracks were done by Rieko Mikoshiba.<ref name="OSTliners"/>
The game's theme song, "[[Zero (Bump of Chicken song)|Zero]]", was composed and performed by Japanese rock band [[Bump of Chicken]].<ref name="Type0themesong"/> The band, which was a big fan of the ''Final Fantasy'' series, was contacted by Square Enix to compose and perform the song and agreed readily. It was brought in after the platform move onto the PSP, but while the game was still titled ''Agito XIII''. While looking for inspiration, the band was able to see in-development screenshots of the game, samples of the script, and character illustrations.<ref name="BoCfamitsu"/> The band was mostly given a free hand while composing the song. Its one guideline was provided by Tabata, who suggested the theme song for ''Centuries of Picture'', "Is Paris Burning?" by Takeshi Kako, as a source of inspiration. Multiple versions of "Zero" were composed for use in different areas of the game.<ref name="T0art"/><ref name="BoCfamitsu"/> At the request of band leader Motoo Fujiwara, Amano's logo artwork was used for the cover of the single's limited edition.<ref name="BoCfamitsu"/>
''Final Fantasy Type-0 Original Soundtrack'' was released on October 26, 2011. The soundtrack was released in a standard edition, as well as a limited edition that could be purchased both separately and with the collector's edition of the game.<ref name="SQEXlimited"/> A promotional album featuring five tracks was sold by Square Enix at their booth at the [[Odaiba|Odaiba Expo 2011]].<ref name="Type0promoOST"/> The album stayed on the [[Oricon]] charts for seven weeks, reaching a high of #25.<ref name="ORICON1"/> The soundtrack has received positive reviews in the west from dedicated music outlets ''Original Sound Version'' and ''Game-OST'', with the sites giving both individual tracks and the work in general high praise.<ref name="GOSTreview"/><ref name="OSVreview"/> "Zero" was released on October 19, 2011. It was released as a single instead of being part of the main soundtrack, receiving both a limited and standard edition.<ref name="BoCfamitsu"/> The single remained in the Oricon charts for thirty-two weeks, peaking at #2.<ref name="ORICON2"/>

==Release== ''Type-0'' was released on October 27, 2011, receiving both physical and digital releases.<ref name="T0delay"/><ref name="TypeReleases"/> It was initially announced for release in summer of that year, but unspecified difficulties with development including the stoppage of PlayStation Network caused a delay.<ref name="AndriaMultiplayer"/> It was then announced for released on October 13, but was delayed by two weeks. While Square Enix stated it wanted to improve its quality, no other information was given. It was speculated to be due to complaints surrounding the camera control and other gameplay elements. The releases of the soundtrack and the theme song were also delayed.<ref name="T0delay"/> ''Type-0'' was one of a few releases for the PSP to be released on two UMDs, as Tabata wanted to cut as little content as possible, which would have been impossible if they had settled for using one UMD.<ref name="AndraiType01"/> A demo for the original game was released in August 2011, featuring seven playable characters and four missions at locked difficulty levels.<ref name="SilDifficulty"/><ref name="DemoRelease"/> Save data could be transferred to the full game, unlocking special costumes and items and keeping experience points.<ref name="T0demo"/> A second demo was released on November 22, a month after the full game's release. It replaced the original demo and gave players access to exclusive items and costumes.<ref name="Type0secondDemo"/> A collector's edition was released exclusively through Square Enix's online store, containing artwork, a limited edition version of the soundtrack, postcards and a booklet of character introductions.<ref name="GemCollector"/> The title was later added to their Ultimate Hits budget title collection.<ref name="UltimateHits"/>
''Type-0'' has never received an official localization in its original form.<ref name="Type-0Update"/> During development, while it was still titled ''Agito XIII'', Tabata said he was trying to make the game appealing to North American players.<ref name="T0appeal"/> Despite a localization being confirmed as in development in an official guidebook interview, the original version of ''Type-0'' was not released in the west.<ref name="T0Olocal"/> In the wake of the game's release in Japan, [[1UP.com]] and [[Joystiq]] speculated that the game could be successfully brought west as a port to the [[PlayStation Vita]].<ref name="T0vita1"/><ref name="T0vita2"/> Tabata later commented that the main reasons for the game not being localized were the flagging Western PSP market and uncertainties surrounding the Vita's commercial success.<ref name="Type-0Update"/>
An unofficial [[Fan translation of video games|fan translation]] [[Patch (computing)|patch]] was announced in mid-2012. Work on the fan translation took place over the following two years, during which time Square Enix was noncommittal concerning an official Western release.<ref name="KotakuFanTranslation"/> The patch was initially announced for an August 2014 release, but was instead was released on June 9, 2014. According to the translation team leader, the patch was downloaded 100,000 times in the first four days.<ref name="KotakuFanTranslation"/><ref name="Type0fan"/> It was taken down in July of the same year after Square Enix allegedly threatened unspecified legal action, originally thought to be a [[cease and desist|cease-and-desist]] order.<ref name="CeaseDesist"/> Later statements revealed that the patch was released earlier than originally announced due to the lead translator on the project wanting fans to see their achievements, which ended up causing a rift between him and the rest of the team. Before the release, Square Enix and the translation team had been in friendly communication concerning the translation. The formal requests to take the patch down were made in the weeks following its release, shortly before the announcement of ''Type-0 HD''.<ref name="KotakuFanTranslation"/> Work on the patch was eventually resumed and a second version, which included unofficial compatibility with the [[PlayStation 3]] system and further translation bugfixes, was eventually released in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skybladecloud.net/we-have-arrived/|title=We have arrived! *UPDATE*|date=2014-06-08|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-11}}</ref>
===Merchandise=== Multiple pieces of merchandise were created for the game. An ''[[List of Square Enix companion books|Ultimania]]'', part of a series of dedicated guidebooks, was released in the same month as the original game. It contained story and character breakdowns, concept art, and interviews with developers.<ref name="SEgameguide"/> A different book, {{Nihongo foot|''Final Fantasy Type-0 World Preview'',|ファイナルファンタジー零式 ワールドプレビュー|Fainaru Fantajī Reishiki Wārudo Purebyū|group=Jp.}} was also released in October. It featured character biographies, details on the world of Orience, and interviews with the voice actors for Class Zero.<ref name="SEworld"/> The following year, a dedicated art book was released containing artwork of the game's characters and monsters, and an interview with Tabata.<ref name="SEgameart"/> Characters from the game, including Ace, Machina and other members of Class Zero, appeared in the fourth series of releases for the ''Final Fantasy Trading Card Game''.<ref name="TradeCard"/> In November 2011, a manga adaptation of ''Type-0'', illustrated by Takatoshi Shiozawa, began serialization in ''[[Gangan Comics|Young Gangan]]'' magazine.<ref name="Type0manga"/> The manga has been collected into a [[tankōbon]] volume and was released on April 21, 2012.<ref name="manga_compilation"/> Another manga titled {{Nihongo foot|''Final Fantasy Type-0 Side Story: Reaper of the Icy Blade'',|ファイナルファンタジー零式外伝 氷剣の死神|Fainaru Fantajī Reishiki Gaiden Hyouken no Shinigami|group=Jp.}} also illustrated by Shiozawa, began publication in ''Young Gangan'' in April 2012.<ref name="2nd-manga"/> It ended in January 2014, with a bonus chapter being published in February of that year,<ref name="manga_end"/><ref name="manga_bonus"/> and was later released in five compiled volumes. [[Yen Press]] began distribution of the manga in the west in July 2015.<ref name="ANNlicense"/> Square Enix released two novel adaptations, in April and June 2012, depicting an alternate version of ''Type-0''{{'}}s story: {{Nihongo foot|''Final Fantasy Type-0: Change the World -The Answer-''|ファイナルファンタジー零式 Change the World -The Answer-|Fainaru Fantajī Reishiki Chenji Za Wārudo -Za Ansā-|group=Jp.}} and {{Nihongo foot|''Final Fantasy Type-0: Change the World Volume 2 -The Penultimate Truth-''.|ファイナルファンタジー零式 Change the World 2巻 -最後から二番目の真実-|Fainaru Fantajī Reishiki Chenji Za Wārudo 2-kan -Banme no Shinjitsu-|group=Jp.}} The novels were written by Sōki Tsukishima.<ref name="Novel-1"/><ref name="Novel-2"/>
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | width = 26m | Fam = 39/40<ref name="FamReview"/> | rev1 = ''[[Dengeki PlayStation]]'' | rev1Score = 91.25/100<ref name="dengeki_review"/> | rev2 = PlayStation LifeStyle | rev2Score = 8/10<ref name="lifestyle0"/> | rev3 = RPG Site | rev3Score = 9/10<ref name="RPGreview"/> }} In the first week on sale, ''Final Fantasy Type-0'' sold 472,253 units, topping Japanese sales charts and selling through 79.08% of its initial shipments.<ref name="T0sales1"/><ref name="Type0shipments"/> As of January 16, 2012, the game had sold 746,203 copies in Japan.<ref name="T0sales2"/> It was the best-selling game of 2011 for Japanese media retail shop [[Culture Convenience Club|Tsutaya]], beating ''[[Monster Hunter Portable 3rd]]'' (PlayStation Portable) and ''[[Final Fantasy XIII-2]]'' (PlayStation 3). It was also the store's best-selling PSP title of the year, followed by ''Monster Hunter Portable 3rd'' and ''[[Dissidia 012 Final Fantasy]]''.<ref name="SiliconSales"/>
''[[Famitsu]]'' and ''[[Dengeki PlayStation]]'' both praised the story, with ''Famitsu'' saying it "vividly portrays the fact that this is a deep, intense ''Final Fantasy'' experience, something beyond just a side story".<ref name="FamReview"/><ref name="dengeki_review"/> Gaming website PlayStation LifeStyle's Heath Hindman was impressed by the darker presentation, calling it "powerful and well done throughout", and was impressed with the characters despite some awkward introductory scenes.<ref name="lifestyle0"/> Erren Van Duine, writing for RPG Site, said that fans would appreciate the scale of the narrative, and praised the handling of the ''Fabula Nova Crystallis'' mythos. She did note that some plot points seemed only included for the sake of convenience, and that the ending forced a second playthrough to see the whole story.<ref name="RPGreview"/>
''Famitsu'' called the original version's gameplay a "stressless experience", praising the game's size and saying the action-oriented battle system made it "a very different ''Final Fantasy''".<ref name="FamReview"/> ''Dengeki PlayStation'' similarly praised its size and the tense combat, though the review found aspects of the navigation less appealing.<ref name="dengeki_review"/> Hindman was generally positive about most aspects of gameplay and the high replay value, but found faults with the scripted opening of the overworld and the real-time strategy segments.<ref name="lifestyle0"/> Van Duine said the gameplay encouraged immersion and was harsh on novices; she praised several aspects of gameplay, but described the leveling system as "tricky".<ref name="RPGreview"/> The multiplayer functions were universally praised in Japan.<ref name="FamReview"/><ref name="dengeki_review"/> Opinions were divided on the original camera, with ''Famitsu'' praising its movement, while Van Duine and ''Dengeki PlayStation'' found issues with it getting stuck in the environment or impeding visibility.<ref name="RPGreview"/><ref name="FamReview"/><ref name="dengeki_review"/> The character AI also received criticism for being unresponsive or wayward.<ref name="RPGreview"/><ref name="lifestyle0"/>
==Legacy== {{main article|Final Fantasy Type-0 HD|Final Fantasy Agito|Final Fantasy Awakening}} ''Type-0'' affected several other works in multiple ways. During its development, several staff members and voice actors who had worked on ''[[Final Fantasy X]]'' reunited. Their meeting triggered the development of ''[[Final Fantasy X/X-2 HD Remaster]]''.<ref name="RemasterOrigin"/> In the September 2013 issue of ''Famitsu Weekly'', Square Enix revealed ''[[Final Fantasy Agito]]'', an online companion game to ''Type-0'' for [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] mobile devices.<ref name="AgitoDetails"/> The game was released in May 2014, and a localization was announced alongside that of ''Type-0''.<ref name="AgitoRelease"/><ref name="AgitoE3"/> Its servers were closed down in November 2015, with its localization being cancelled as a result.<ref name="AgitoVersionEnd"/><ref name="AgitoInternational"/> A new online game set in the ''Type-0'' universe, ''[[Final Fantasy Awakening]]'', released in Asian and English-speaking territories between 2016 and 2018.<ref name="TypeOnline"/>
While working on ''Final Fantasy XV'', Tabata decided to make a high-definition remaster of ''Type-0'' for eighth-generation consoles. Developed by Square Enix and [[HexaDrive]], ''[[Final Fantasy Type-0 HD]]'' was originally announced at E3 2014, and released worldwide in March 2015.<ref name="Type0hex"/><ref name="Type0west"/> After ''Type-0''{{'}}s release, Tabata stated in an interview that he wished to explore the distant history of Orience after the events of the game.<ref name="GamespotTabata"/> Trademarks for ''Type-1'', ''Type-2'' and ''Type-3'' were registered shortly after the ''Type-0'' trademark, but it was suggested that they were simply a protective measure.<ref name="TypesTrademarks"/> During interviews given in 2014, Tabata commented that he wished to work on ''Type-1'' after completing ''XV'', and later explained the conceptual ''Type'' series as a means of publishing ''Final Fantasy'' games too experimental for the main series. He hoped to continue with the ''Type'' series if ''Type-0 HD'' was commercially successful.<ref name="ParisTabata"/><ref name="GemTabataInterviews"/>

page.title: Geneva Academy of International Humanitarian Law and Human Rights

revision.text:
{{multiple issues | {{COI|date=August 2018}} {{peacock|date=August 2018}} {{advert|date=March 2017}} }} {{Infobox academic division | name = Geneva Academy of International humanitarian law and Human Rights | native_name = Académie de droit international humanitaire et de droits humains à Genève | image_name = Villa Moynier.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = Villa Moynier | motto = | motto_lang = | motto_eng = | established = {{Start date|2007}} | closed = | type = | parent = | affiliation = University of Geneva; The Graduate Institute | city = Geneva | canton = GE | prefecture = | province = | region = | state = | country = Switzerland | coor = | dean = | rector = | director = Professor Marco Sassòli | academic_staff = | students = | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | alumni = | symbol = | website = {{URL|www.geneva-academy.ch}} }} '''The Geneva Academy of international Humanitarian Law and Human Rights''' ({{Lang-fr|Académie de droit international humanitaire et de droits humains à Genève}}) is a postgraduate joint center (between the [[University of Geneva]] and the [[Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies]]) located in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]]. The faculty includes professors from both founding institutions and guest professors from major universities .<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geneva-academy.ch/alumni/selected-alumni-profiles/profile |title=Profiles |publisher=Geneva-academy.ch |date= |accessdate=2014-06-10}}</ref>
The alumni include many actors of the humanitarian world, executives of various organizations across the world and foreign affairs executives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geneva-academy.ch/alumni/selected-alumni-profiles/profile |title=Profiles |publisher=Geneva-academy.ch |date= |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref> The school has a diverse student body of a cosmopolitan character due to its 80 percent intake of international students.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geneva-academy.ch/llm-master/prospective-students/admission |title=Geneva Academy of International Humanitarian Law and Human rights - Admission |publisher=Geneva-academy.ch |date= |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref> It is located on the shores of the [[Lake Geneva]] (lac Léman) blocks from the [[United Nations]] headquarters in Europe, and the [[Palace of Nations]] as well as the [[Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies]].
It is located in the Villa Moynier building, built in 1847 and owned by [[Gustave Moynier]], co-founder of the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]].
== History == From August 2014 to August 2018, the Geneva Academy was directed by Professor Robert Roth. In August 2018, Professor Marco Sassòli became the new Director of the Geneva Academy. He has been Professor of International Law at the University of Geneva Law Faculty since 2004 and has been teaching IHL at the Geneva Academy since this time. He is Associate Professor at the University of Quebec in Montreal (Canada), Commissioner of the International Commission of Jurists and Special Advisor (pro bono) on IHL to the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, and has previously worked for the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) as Deputy Head of its Legal Division in Geneva and Head of Delegation in the field.<ref>http://graduateinstitute.ch/home/relations-publiques/news-at-the-institute/news-archives.html/_/news/corporate/2014/new-director-of-the-academy-of-h</ref>
== Master's programmes == The Geneva Academy offers three master's programmes: * LLM in International Humanitarian Law and Human Rights<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unige.ch/formcont/IHL.html |title=MAS - LL.M. International Humanitarian Law and Human Rights / Droit international humanitaire et droits humains - Formation continue - UNIGE |publisher=Unige.ch |date=2014-03-04 |accessdate=2014-06-10}}</ref> * Master of Advanced Studies in Transitional Justice, Human Rights and the Rule of Law<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unige.ch/formcont/mastransitionaljustice/|title=MAS - Transitional Justice, Human Rights and the Rule of Law - Centre de formation continue et à distance - UNIGE|website=www.unige.ch|language=fr|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref> * Executive Master in International Law in Armed Conflict<ref>{{cite web|url=http://graduateinstitute.ch/home/executive/programmes_conjoints.html |title=Joint Programmes |publisher=Graduateinstitute.ch |date= |accessdate=2014-06-10}}</ref>
== Training and short courses == The Geneva Academy offers a range of training and short courses for professionals on legal issues related to armed conflicts, human rights protection, transitional justice and international criminal justice.
== Research ==
The Geneva Academy conducts legal research and policy studies in the fields of international law in armed conflict, human rights protection, transitional justice, international criminal justice, weapons law, or [[economic, social and cultural rights]].
Current research projects include the protection of persons with disabilities during and following armed conflicts, human rights responsibilities and armed non-state actors, human rights and gender equality in the context of business activities, or the rights of peasants.
The Geneva Academy also runs the online platform Rule of Law in Armed Conflicts (RULAC) that systematically qualifies situations of armed violence using the definition of armed conflict under international humanitarian law.
The Geneva Academy is home to the Swiss Chair of International Humanitarian Law, currently held by Noam Lubell, Professor of International Law of Armed Conflict, in the School of Law, [[University of Essex]], UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geneva-academy.ch/the-academy/faculty-a-staff/faculty/swiss-chair-of-international-humanitarian-law |title=Geneva Academy of International Humanitarian Law and Human Rights - Swiss Chair of International Humanitarian Law |publisher=Geneva-academy.ch |date= |accessdate=2014-06-10}}</ref> and the Human Rights Chair, currently held by Professor [[Nils Melzer]], UN Special Rapporteur on torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/Issues/Torture/SRTorture/Pages/SRTortureIndex.aspx|title=Special Rapporteur on torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment|website=www.ohchr.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref>
== Villa Moynier ==
[[File:Geneva Villa Moynier 1.jpg|thumb|Geneva Villa Moynier]] The Geneva Academy is headquartered at the Villa Moynier, a historic villa surrounded by a beautiful park with a view of [[Lake Geneva]] and [[Mont Blanc]]. It was the property of [[Gustave Moynier]], the first President of the [[International Committee of the Red Cross|ICRC]]. It later housed the League of Nations in 1926 and served as headquarters for the ICRC between 1933 and 1946. Villa Moynier forms part of the Graduate Institute’s [[Campus de la paix]] and is five minutes’ walk from the [[Maison de la paix]].

The Growing Participator Approach (GPA) is an alternative paradigm for [[Second-language acquisition|second language acquisition]] created by Greg Thomson.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://growingparticipatorapproach.blogspot.com|title=Growing Participator Approach to a host world (An Alternative to "Second Language Acquisition")|website=growingparticipatorapproach.blogspot.com|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref> In GPA, the goal is not language acquisition, but participation in the life of a new community, which is constantly growing over time. Thus, GPA uses the terminology of a 'growing participator' instead of a language learner, and a 'nurturer' instead of a teacher. Theoretically, GPA draws upon James Wersch's sociocultural theory and concepts of mediated learning, along with [[Lev Vygotsky]]'s [[zone of proximal development]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite thesis|last=Andrew|first=Sawin, Thor|title=Second Language Learnerhood Among Cross-Cultural Field Workers|date=2013|publisher=University of South Carolina|url=http://scholarcommons.sc.edu/etd/1534|language=en}}p.149.</ref> In the [[Language pedagogy|language of pedagogy]], GPA involves an approach, a method, and techniques.
== Approach == Thomson suggests three dimensions of language learning (or participation) which are important for GPA.
=== Sociocultural Dimension === GPA views language as inseparable from the culture which supports it and the people who live in that culture and their relationships. This sociocultural dimension is fundamental.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mas, Roser Noguera and Baiguatova, Gulnara|first=|date=2015-04-10|title=Growing Participator Approach: Our Experience as Amharic Students and Teachers of Spanish and Russian Languages|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1877042815019680|journal=Procedia - Social and Behavioral Sciences|language=en|volume=178|pages=169–174|doi=10.1016/j.sbspro.2015.03.175|issn=1877-0428|via=}}</ref> Thus, instead of learning language in isolation, the goal is to learn a new way of life (languaculture). Hence, GPA uses the terminology of "growing participators" rather than "language learners". The goal of a growing participator is to learn and grow into a new "languacultural world".<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://growingparticipatorapproach.wordpress.com/the-growing-participator-approach-gpa-a-brief-state-of-the-art-and-some-practical-illustrations/|title=The Growing Participator Approach (GPA): A Brief State of the Art and Some Practical Illustrations|last=Thomson|first=Greg|date=2012|work=Growing Participator Approach|access-date=2018-10-13|language=en-US}}</ref> This happens most effectively when a learner is operating within their growth zone ([[Zone of proximal development|ZPD]]).
=== Cognitive Dimension === Drawing on fields of psycholinguistics, and noting that good comprehension of English speech requires a listening vocabulary of over 10,000 words, GPA emphasizes "massive comprehension vocabulary." However, instead of rote memorisation, GPA advocates for continual exposure, "encountering a massive amount of understandable speech over a long period of time", in order to slowly internalize vocabulary without trying to memorise one by one.<ref name=":1" /> Thus, GPA emphasises comprehension and listening far ahead of speech in the host language.
=== Temporal Dimension === All language programs emphasize time, but in GPA the focus is not on quantity of time, but on quality. GPA aims for at least 15 hours/week during which "people interact with me in my growth zone in their languacultural world."<ref name=":1" /> As a result, because a beginning learner's growth zone is that of a child, in order for GPA to be put into practice a dedicated native speaker must be hired in the early stages.
=== Language Acquisition in GPA === Based on these three dimensions, GPA's approach can be summarised as follows: {| class="wikitable" |+Presuppositions about Language Acquisition in GPA<ref>Cassi, Heidi (2005). [http://www.hamline.edu/WorkArea/DownloadAsset.aspx?id=2147490891 The Thomson method of study for second language acquisition: A diary study]. (Thesis). St. Paul, MN: Hamline University, p.23.</ref> | rowspan="5" |Communing |1. Second language acquisition occurs through comprehension of real messages |- |2. Messages must contain input that is a little more than the level the learner currently understands (i.e. in their growth zone). |- |3. Acquisition occurs when the learner is focusing on something other than acquisition (i.e. focus on the message). |- |4. Second language acquisition occurs when the learner is not ‘on the defensive’. |- |5. The learning environment should be comfortable and should keep anxiety levels low. |- | rowspan="7" |Understanding |6. Second language acquisition produces listening skills prior to speaking skills. |- |7. Learners should be given a “silent period”. |- |8. Second language acquisition is not conscious interaction with/awareness of grammar rules. |- |9. Consciously learned grammar is a tool for specific tasks, such as writing and editing, and should be used when time allows. |- |10. Second language acquisition does involve the acquisition of grammatical structures, generally in a predictable order. However, this does not mean we should try to teach grammar according to this order. |- |11. Subconsciously acquired language is responsible for initiating utterances and for fluency. |- |12. Conscious learning does have a role, but not a central role, in second language acquisition. |- | rowspan="3" |Talking |13. Second language acquisition does not require tedious drilling. |- |14. Production develops gradually and is not taught directly. |- |15. Second language acquisition takes time and develops slowly/subtly as opposed to learning which can be fast/obvious for some people. |- | rowspan="2" |Evolving |16. Focus of study should remain on receiving quality input, not on receiving error correction. |- |17. Activities should be adjusted to keep the learner comprehending and processing target language. |}
== Method == The ''Six-Phase Program'' (SPP), created by Thomson, is "an idealised program to guide a growing participator into deep involvement with a community."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://growingparticipatorapproach.wordpress.com/an-idealized-program-six-phases-of-super-charged-activities/|title=An Idealized Program ~ Six Phases of Super-Charged Activities|date=2013-01-17|work=Growing Participator Approach|access-date=2018-10-13|language=en-US}}</ref> It involves 1,500 hours of special-growth activities, assisted (initially) by a dedicated native speaker - who does not need to be a teacher. It is "structured in such a way that the activities become increasingly advanced as the user grows, and the activities are "keyed to the sociocultural/human-relationship changes and cognitive changes that the growing participator (GP) undergoes."<ref name=":1" />
=== Overview of the Six-Phase Program === {| class="wikitable" ! !Name !Communication Ability !Hrs !Vocab learnt |- |1 |'''Connecting''' |I understand what I hear if I can clearly see what is being talked about (objects, activities, locations, simple situations, etc.). |100 |750 |- |2 |'''Emerging''' |With the use of visual supports (picture stories, stick figures, blocks, etc.), a host person and I begin to create stories together. |150 |2,250 (+1500) |- |3 |'''Knowable''' |A host person talks to me about things I already know & we discuss them simply (e.g. common stories). |250 |3,500 (+1250) |- |4 |'''Deep Personal Relationships''' |Several host people take me more deeply into their lives, and in the process we share our stories and lives together. |500 |6,000 (+2500) |- |5 |'''Widening Understanding''' |I listen a lot to host people talking with other host people. I find frequent gaps in my understanding and fill them in. |500 |9,000 (+3500) |- |6 |'''Ever Growing Participation''' |I understand almost all I hear, and it feeds my growth in communication ability. | - |<nowiki>-</nowiki> |}
=== Techniques === GPA and the SPP utilise a wide array of techniques, such as [[Total physical response|TPR]] activities (in silence for the first 30-40 hrs), back and forth storytelling, wordless picture books, discussing speech acts with the use of resources such as [http://www.lexicarry.com/ Lexicarry], input/output flooding, ethnographic interviews, and extensive recording and playback for revision.

S. Eliot]] }} '''Guido Monte''' (born 1962 - died 2017) was an [[Italians|Italian]] writer and poet. In his mature works, he employed linguistic blending in the search for meaningful and archetypal relations between distant cultures.[http://www.mid.muohio.edu/segue/contributors2.htm Monte's bio on ''Segue'', mid.muohio.edu] of [[Miami University Middletown]] His works and translations have been published by international magazines (as ''[[Words Without Borders]]'',[http://wordswithoutborders.org/contributor/guido-monte Monte on ''Words Without Borders'']. WWB is the magazine of Alane Salierno Mason, translator of [[Elio Vittorini]]. ''[[Swans (magazine)|Swans Commentary]]'', and ''[[Ars Interpres]]''). On his blending experiments, he uses also Japanese, [http://happano.sub.jp/happano/pages/fragments/63.html ''Dapur Vetur'', on ''Happa no kofu''] [[Sanskrit]], [http://www.swans.com/library/art14/gmonte42.html ''Journey n.6...'' on ''Swans Commentary''] [[Sheng (linguistics)|Sheng]][http://www.swans.com/library/art13/gmonte14.html ''written on my sanbenito'', on ''Swans Commentary''] and languages of ethnic groups in [[Kenya]]. == Poetry and linguistic blending == On the way of [[Jorge Luis Borges]], [[Ezra Pound]]'s ''Cantos'' and [[T. S. Eliot]]'s ''[[The Waste Land]]'', Monte thinks that "…if we admit that some archetypal ideas are common among our planet inhabitants, then we can state, in the sense meant by Borges, that just one "Book" has been written, as an evidence of the original and permanent cultural unity of the world and it contains all the chaotic fragments ever thought and written by people searching for the deep truth of things…".[http://www.happano.org/pages/fragments/63-2.html ''Cosmopolitan multilingualism'', on ''Happa no kofu''] Different languages can be approached and mixed "to transmit something that apparently is far in space and time" (on what was defined as ''a meta-communicative way''[http://www.swans.com/library/art13/saieva01.html Francesca Saieva, ''Linguistic Blending. A Way...'' Swans.com]). On this thinking, a ''blending'' author can "compose" poems and works without using his own verses, but only other poets' lines (and sometimes this is Monte's peculiarity), remembering every time, in the beginning, the names of the authors. On another experiment, in fact, Monte puts together, in a common archetypal idea, lines of [[Virgil]], Dante and Blake.[http://www.mid.muohio.edu/segue/4.2/Segue%204-2.swf ''Origines'', on ''Segue''] If Monte translates, for instance, the first verses of Genesis or any other holy texts in two or three languages, "…we realize that the new and different sounds, irrespective of our linguistic knowledge, suggest new, universal, cosmic vibrations that the original version didn't succeed in transmitting. In any case they reveal the complexity of reading different levels": ''In principio diviserunt Elohim / coelum et terram / and the land was left barren / et les ombres noires / enveloppaient les profondeurs / bade korgolòdei dar ruie / oghionusoh parmisad / et aura divina / super oceani undas'' (''Genesis'', Words Without Borders, 2004)[http://wordswithoutborders.org/article/genesis-creation/ Monte on ''Words Without Borders''] Alison Phipps, expert in Intercultural Studies, defines this form of blending as an ''embroidering gossamer''.[http://www.swans.com/library/past_issues/2008/080922.html Swans commentary, sept.2008]. [http://researchingmultilingually.com/?page_id=806 Alison Phipps] (Professor of Languages and Intercultural Studies at the University of Glasgow) about it: ''“It is good to think with others about how languages find their way into the cracks and crevices of our lives – how they create a gossamer of relatedness which always has an unpredictable feel and future”''. ([http://www.swans.com/library/art14/gmonte52.html A.Phipps on ''Swans Commentary'', 2008]). About her collaboration in eSharp project, see [http://www.sojel.co.uk/SOJEL/Sojel%20Papers/Sojel%20June%202007%20issue.pdf "Views from the bridge: publishing as a voyage of discovery", SOJEL, June 2007].
In his latest experiments, on [[Swans (magazine)|Swans Commentary]], the [[Visual poetry|visual]] coloured arrangement of verses (one colour for each one of the poem's selected authors) is important in conveying the intended effect of his [[Multilingualism|multilingual]] works.About Monte and his new blending approach, the French translator [http://www.champendal.com/docs/Le_Rugbyman_Nomade_Richard_Beard.pdf Marie Rennard] said :''"...sa démarche demande à être expliquée, la " résonnance cosmique " qu'il évoque peut faire sourire au prime abord, et pourtant, à le lire, à le relire, on sent naître cette communion des verbes de toutes langues, et sans être forcément à même de saisir toute l'ampleur d'une démarche qui, selon son propre aveu, le dépasse lui-même, on éprouve le plaisir profond que font naître les véritables poètes à l'oreille d'en dedans, pur bonheur, mere happiness, autentica felicità''". ([http://storage.canalblog.com/90/28/320433/17561486.doc ''Langues et mixité'', Introduction de Marie Rennard)]) The French writer Orlando de Rudder,de Rudder teaches Medieval Literature and History of French Language at the ''Ecole Superieure de Commerce'' of Paris, (see [http://www.bibliopoche.com/auteur/De-Rudder-Orlando/23495.html bibliopoche.com] and [http://www.terascia.com/article.php?sid=470 terascia.com]) thinks that Monte's attempts are the beginning of a new ''"synthèse" des langues'', a form of ''Babel Library'' where all the world poets live together, syncretistically, common universal feelings.[http://orlandoderudder.canalblog.com/archives/2006/09/14/2678504.html comment on de Rudder's blog] The Italian writer [[Claudio Magris]] thinks that this kind of poetry is definable as ''meticciato organico'' (''organic blending'').[http://www.swans.com/library/art17/saieva04.html swans.com, 25 avril 2011]; about Monte's blending, see also the opinion of Magris on [http://riviste.unimi.it/index.php/inkoj/article/view/2388/2617 In Koj] (University of Milan, p.208 ==Selected bibliography== * ''Tremila mondi in un solo istante di vita'', ed. The [[screenplay]] was written by [[John McGreevey]] and Frank Telford. Its 1974 re-release was part of the "Paramount Family Matinee" series. ==Plot== Fred Miller ([[Tony Randall]]) must prove that his new design for an underwater home is viable by convincing his family to live in it for 30 days. His son and daughter (Gary Tigerman and Kay Cole) are members of an emerging pop rock band ([[Richard Dreyfuss]] and [[Lou Wagner]]) whom they invite to live with them during the experiment. Their temporary home, which Miller dubs the "Green Onion," is 90 feet below the surface of the ocean and is filled with super-modern appliances and amenities for house-wife Vivian ([[Janet Leigh]]), all designed by Miller. A hole in the floor provides direct access to and from the sea. The group are soon joined by a live-in [[Pinniped|seal]] named Gladys and a pair of dolphins (Duke and Duchess), which stay close at hand and fend off unwanted sharks. They are confronted by many obstacles including a rival designer ([[Ken Berry]]) from Undersea Development, Inc. who begins to cause problems.[https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9900EFDC133AEE34BC4E51DFB0668382679EDE Weiler, A. H. ''Hello Down There (1969) Undersea Rock 'n' Roll'', (1969-06-26) ''The New York Times''], retrieved 2009-03-19. Meanwhile, the band's single has gotten the attention of record executive Nate Ashbury ([[Roddy McDowall]]), who decides to sign them sight-unseen. He takes the liberty of booking them for an important television performance on ''[[The Merv Griffin Show]]'' without first communicating with them. After learning that they are inaccessible under the sea, he proves that the show must go on and that he will go to great lengths to reach them. They get their airing on television, but the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] is put on alert by the sounds of music coming from the sea. A naval fleet is dispatched to investigate what must surely be a Communist plot! ==Cast== * [[Tony Randall]] as Fred Miller * [[Janet Leigh]] as Vivian Miller * [[Jim Backus]] as T.R. Hollister * [[Ken Berry]] as Mel Cheever * [[Roddy McDowall]] as Nate Ashbury * [[Charlotte Rae]] as Myrtle Ruth * [[Richard Dreyfuss]] as Harold Webster * Kay Cole as Lorrie Miller * Gary Tigerman as Tommie Miller * [[Lou Wagner]] as Marvin Webster * [[Bruce Gordon (actor)|Bruce Gordon]] as Adm. Sheridan * Frank Schuller as Alan Briggs * [[Arnold Stang]] as Jonah * [[Harvey Lembeck]] as Sonarman * [[Merv Griffin]] as Himself * [[Henny Backus]] as Mrs. Webster * Pat Henning as Reilly * Jay Laskay as Philo * Bud Hoey as Mr. Webster * Charles Martin as Chief Petty Officer * Frank Logan as Captain * Andy Jarrell as Radioman * Lora Kaye as Secretary ==Production== ''Hello Down There'' was filmed from October to December 1967, with interior scenes shot at Ivan Tors Studios (now known as Greenwich Studios) in [[Miami|Miami, Florida]]. The underwater sequences were photographed at Ivan Tors Underwater Studios in [[The Bahamas]]. ==Music Soundtrack== "Hello Down There" and "Little Goldfish" are two songs on the film's soundtrack. Unfortunately, the soundtrack cannot be purchased separately.
